title: Polish air force may still need to import expensive fuel for operations
description:
In 2022, Orlen’s then-CEO Daniel Obajtek announced a new installation in Płock to produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) domestically.
The project, however, has been delayed by at least a year, forcing Poland to rely on expensive imports.
Under EU ReFuelEU Aviation rules, airlines must gradually increase SAF use—from 2% in 2025 to 70% by 2050—but global supply remains limited and costly.
Orlen now plans to start operations in 2026, initially producing components for diesel rather than SAF.
They argue that real progress lies in fuel-efficient aircraft and new engine technologies, not costly SAF mandates.
text:
In 2022, Orlen’s then-CEO Daniel Obajtek announced a new installation in Płock to produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) domestically. The project, however, has been delayed by at least a year, forcing Poland to rely on expensive imports. Under EU ReFuelEU Aviation rules, airlines must gradually increase SAF use—from 2% in 2025 to 70% by 2050—but global supply remains limited and costly.

Orlen now plans to start operations in 2026, initially producing components for diesel rather than SAF. The company cites high raw material prices and limited access to waste-based feedstock, mostly controlled by Asian suppliers.

As a result, Ryanair and LOT face soaring costs—about $200 million and 100 million PLN respectively—just to meet environmental targets, eating into annual profits. Airline executives criticize EU policy, warning it undermines competitiveness against non-EU carriers. They argue that real progress lies in fuel-efficient aircraft and new engine technologies, not costly SAF mandates.

title: Government-commissioned review says net zero not possible without CCUS
description:
The Independent Review of Greenhouse Gas Removals (GGRs), which was commissioned by the government, has found that “without GGRs we cannot meet net zero”.
The review was commissioned by the Department for Energy Security and Net Zero (DESNZ) in February 2025 and was led by former Labour shadow energy minister Alan Whitehead.
In September 2025, Heidelberg Materials UK’s carbon capture and storage (CCS) project to decarbonise a cement works achieved its final investment decision (FID).
GGRs critical to achieving net zero – review Introducing the report, Whitehead said: “Do we need GGRs to get us to net zero?
CCUS industry welcomes review and pledges to promote the technology CCSA (Carbon Capture and Storage Association) UK director Mark Sommerfeld said: “The Independent Review of Greenhouse Gas Removals marks a pivotal step in the UK’s net zero journey.
text:
The Independent Review of Greenhouse Gas Removals (GGRs), which was commissioned by the government, has found that “without GGRs we cannot meet net zero”.

The review was commissioned by the Department for Energy Security and Net Zero (DESNZ) in February 2025 and was led by former Labour shadow energy minister Alan Whitehead.

GGRs useful for preventing GHGs from entering atmosphere

Greenhouse gas removal technologies, also known as carbon capture, utilisation and storage (CCUS), are being deployed in the UK to enable the continued burning of natural gas without releasing the associated greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions into the atmosphere, which would otherwise accelerate climate breakdown.

While there are plenty of technological solutions to replacing natural gas as a source of electricity generation, such as renewable energy and battery storage, CCUS is also used to mitigate the GHG emissions of hard-to-abate sectors such as cement production.

In September 2025, Heidelberg Materials UK’s carbon capture and storage (CCS) project to decarbonise a cement works achieved its final investment decision (FID).

GGRs critical to achieving net zero – review

Introducing the report, Whitehead said: “Do we need GGRs to get us to net zero? All the evidence points to a firm ‘yes’, unless we can contemplate a low-carbon future with no industry, little transport and difficult-to-swallow mass behaviour change.

“Estimates of the ‘gap’ left after all reasonable steps to decarbonise have been taken vary, but all conclude that the only way to overcome the ‘emissions gap’ is to deploy to varying degrees the sheaf of removal technologies now being developed.”

The review concluded that “without GGRs we cannot meet net zero, and the value of doing so in a way that achieves geological net zero”, however, it added “that there is no silver bullet” to decarbonising the economy.

It presented a series of recommendations to the government. It said the “government should develop a GGR Strategy to outline the contribution of GGR solutions required to meet carbon budgets and net zero”.

In addition, the review said the government should “establish an Office for Greenhouse Gas Removals to produce more coordinated action on GGRs, and to enable quicker and more efficient rollout of policy and project deployment”.

The government has recently said that it wants to reduce the number of quangos (quasi-autonomous non-government organisations). That didn’t stop it from recently creating the Office for Clean Energy Jobs (OCEJ) to help deliver the 400,000 new clean energy jobs by 2030 which it says are needed for the journey to net zero.

The review added that the government “should adopt a strategic aim to minimise the use of imported biomass feedstocks” and it should “amend and rename the SAF [sustainable aviation fuel] Mandate to become a Net Zero Aviation Mandate, with a trajectory that means that by 2045 all flights taking off from the UK are made climate neutral.

“The amended Mandate should drive procurement of both SAF and permanent GGRs, with competition between these solutions.”

The final recommendation was that the government should “exploit UK growth opportunities” by making the UK a leader in deploying and promoting GGR technologies.

CCUS industry welcomes review and pledges to promote the technology

CCSA (Carbon Capture and Storage Association) UK director Mark Sommerfeld said: “The Independent Review of Greenhouse Gas Removals marks a pivotal step in the UK’s net zero journey.

“Technologies such as Bioenergy with CCS, Direct Air Capture with Storage and Energy from Waste with CCS are essential to tackling residual emissions, addressing industrial decarbonisation and securing a reliable, low-carbon energy system.

“The Review outlines a clear path to scale these solutions, with success hinging on a credible business model, investment certainty and robust CO₂ transport and storage infrastructure.

“With vast CO₂ storage potential, established CCUS infrastructure and world-leading low-carbon expertise, the UK has a real opportunity to be a global leader in high-integrity carbon removals.

“We look forward to working with the government and industry to deliver 5 Mtpa of engineered removals by 2030, rising to 23 Mtpa by 2035 – boosting growth, energy security and addressing climate change as global demand for GGR credits surges.”

Review ‘blinkered by a silo mentality’ – anti-CCUS campaign

Scrap Carbon Capture campaign lead campaigner Andrew Boswell said: “Dr Whitehead’s review is blinkered by a silo mentality.

“It treats greenhouse-gas removals (GGRs) as a standalone fix while ignoring the huge externalities built into relying on the Government’s CCS network to deliver them.

“Every UK cluster is front-loaded with fossil-fuel anchor projects that lock in decades of methane-leaking LNG imports and billions in public subsidies ultimately paid by consumers.

“Whitehead calls for faster CCUS expansion but never counts the carbon or economic cost of that dependence.

“He also sidesteps the Drax issue — the UK’s biggest emitter being re-badged as our flagship BECCS [Bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage] project, fuelled by imported forest biomass.

“And his proposal to use GGRs to offset aviation growth misuses scarce removal capacity: these technologies should be for cleaning the atmosphere, not for licensing airport expansion.

“Until we decouple GGR policy from fossil and aviation interests, we’re subsidising the problem, not the solution.”

Minister says government will continue to improve GGR deployment

Energy minister Michael Shanks said: “Greenhouse Gas Removal technologies have the potential to propel us towards our climate targets, as the UK continues to be a world leader on climate action, protecting current and future generations.

“The report recognises the important role GGR technologies can play in delivering clean power and net zero. Already, we are investing in first-of-a-kind carbon capture projects in the UK, – creating thousands of jobs in North Wales, the North West and Teesside.

“We will take the time to carefully consider these findings and consider how best to use these technologies to deliver climate action, good jobs and energy security for the country.”
